bibl.title: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Cooke sends Hench his recollections of the experiments at Camp Lazear. He says that it was so long ago that his memory fails him as to many details.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940
div1.opener:
Lexington ???
Sept 12th 1940
Dr Philip S. Hench
Rochester Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
As requested in your letter of Sept 6th
I enclose a short and, I fear, poorly
written story of the Walter Reed experimen.
tal work on Yellow Fever in which
I participated to the extent Ill. forth.

It has been so long ago that
my memory fails me as to many
details - As I state our squad
was the first to enter one of the buildings
of this I think my memory is correct.
Kissinger's case was the first controlled
experiment in which there could be no doubt
that it was solely due to the bets of an
infeclis insect and the onset of his
attack was about four days after we
entered the other building - Whether he
slept all this time, prior to the. onset
I don't recall. Hoping this little story
may be of some help, to you I am
